Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Origin and Role of Dense Molecular Gas in Star-Forming Galaxies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team will use the Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope (GBT) to observe the dense gas in nearby galaxies. The team has added a cutting-edge instrument, Argus, to this NSF facility. This has paved the way for these important observations at millimeter wavelengths. The team will study how galaxies form stars in their dense gas. They will compare their observations to theoretical models. Senior team members will train junior members recruited from underrepresented groups. The team will feature the research in materials for the Bay Area Science Festival in California and the Green Bank Visitors Center in West Virginia. The team will also help others use Argus for their own research.

The team will use Argus on the GBT to map the dense molecular gas in nearby galaxies at high spatial resolution. They will combine these new data with existing data at other wavelengths to study (1) how the amount of star formation per unit of dense gas depends on the local conditions in the galaxies, and (2) how the amount of dense gas depends on the local conditions in the galaxies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant "Collaborative Research: The Origin and Role of Dense Molecular Gas in Star-Forming Galaxies" supported a variety of observational investigations into how stars form in galaxies, the training of new graduate students, and the application of new technologies to study a difficult astronomical problem of broad importance.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Stars are understood to form from cold, dusty clouds of interstellar gas, mostly hydrogen. Star formation results when gravity manages to trigger the collapse of gas, and dense gas experiences more self-gravity than rare gas. Therefore, the density of interstellar, molecular gas has long been viewed as a property crucial to star formation. A longstanding question in the field is whether density is the only quantity that determines whether gas forms stars.

To investigate this, this grant supported new observations of rotational line emission emitted by the molecules HCN and HCO+ in nearby galaxies. These spectral lines are preferentially created by dense molecular gas, the type of material hyopthesized to represent the direct fuel for future star formation. But the emission from these molecules is so faint that it has required modern technological developments to measure it in even the nearest, brightest star-forming galaxies. The grant supported a combination of survey design, observations, and analysis using the Green Bank Telescope, the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array, and the Institut de Radioastronomie Millimétrique 30-m telescope. We used these telescopes to construct some of the first sensitive, wide-area maps tracing the distribution of dense, possibly star-forming gas across a sample of nearby galaxies.

We contrasted the location of the HCN and HCO+ line emission with emission from the CO molecule, which traces almost all of the cold gas in galaxies. This contrast offers an observational tracer of how dense the gas in galaxies appears to be. Based on these measurements, we showed that while gas density does play an important role in determining whether gas forms stars, the exact role of gas density depends on context. Specifically, dense gas in the centers of galaxies and in high-pressure parts of galaxies appears to form stars less effectively than dense gas in other parts of galaxies. These results support a new, though not totally proven, picture in which the role of gas density in star formation depends on galactic context. This makes an important, but not yet perfectly theoretically understood, contribution to our knowledge of where stars come from and how galaixies grow and evolve.

The exact interpretation of these spectral line observations combining HCN, HCO+, CO and other molecules is complex. The grant also partially supported new theoretical investigations of how physical conditions in the interstellar medium give rise to these lines. This work showed how ensembles of densities can combine to produce the line ratios measured by telescopes. This implies that there is nuance and complexity that needs to be applied to the intepretation of these spectral lines.

BROADER IMPACTS: The grant played an important role in supporting the training of multiple Ph.D. students and the deployment and application of new instrument technology on the Green Bank Telescope. The Ph.D. students received hands on training in observations using a world class telescope, and also gained training in spectroscopy, data analysis, and scientific paper writing. The majority of the scientific publications and observing programs supported by this grant were led by scientists at the graduate student or postdoc level.

This grant also supported the development of the first major extragalactic survey by the ARGUS receiver array at the GBT and hands-on observing, analysis, and scientific training for several students at Ohio State University. ARGUS represents a major technological achievement for one of the U.S.'s leading radio observatories, and the work for this grant helped refine its operation, develop pipelines for data processing, and demonstrate its capabilities.
